questions.text: Which one of the following is FALSE regarding confounding factors in epidemiological studies? (FMGE JUNE 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Associated both with exposure and disease

options.label: B
options.text: Distributed equally between study and control groups

questions.correct_answer: B. Distributed equally between study and control groups
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Distributed equally between study and control groups

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A confounding factor is a variable that is associated with both the exposure and the outcome, and it can distort the apparent relationship between the two. For a variable to be a confounder, it must meet the following criteria:
  • • • It is associated with the exposure.
  • • • It is an independent risk factor for the outcome.
  • • • It is not an intermediate step in the causal pathway between the exposure and the outcome.
  • • In a well-conducted study, confounding factors are typically distributed unequally between the study and control groups, which is why they must be controlled for through various methods such as matching, randomization, stratification, or statistical modeling.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Associated both with exposure and disease: This is true. A confounding factor must be associated with both the exposure and the outcome.
  • • Option A. Associated both with exposure and disease:
  • • Option C. Independent risk factor for disease: This is true. A confounding factor must be an independent risk factor for the outcome.
  • • Option C. Independent risk factor for disease:
  • • Option D. Source of bias in interpretation: This is true. Confounding can introduce bias into the interpretation of the relationship between exposure and outcome, making it appear stronger or weaker
  • • Option D. Source of bias in interpretation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Confounding factors are not typically distributed equally between study and control groups. Effective study design and analysis techniques are necessary to control for these confounders to ensure accurate interpretation of results.

This particular study tracked expectant mothers' smoking habits and the subsequent birth weights of their newborns. Based on this information, which type of epidemiological study design is most likely being used in the research mentioned?
questions.explanation:

  • • Explanation:

In the context of the study described, pregnant women (the cohort) are being followed prospectively from the point of their smoking exposure to the outcome of interest, which is the birth weight of their newborns. This design allows for the temporal relationship between exposure and outcome to be established, which is crucial in understanding causal inferences.

Retrospective Cohort Study: This study design also follows a group of individuals based on exposure status to an outcome, but the data collection starts after the outcomes have occurred, often relying on past records.
